subject: RE: [junit] unit test case for login()
msgSnippet: Based on your sample code you are trying to test Documentum. I ve tried (very hard) to build junit tests into my custom code for this product. I ran into the
messageBody:
Based on your sample code you are trying to test Documentum.

I've tried (very hard) to build junit tests into my custom code for this
product. I ran into the same set of problems each time I tried. The
Documentum API is so complex and has so many interacting parts that
generally I was not able to dedicate the time required to create anything
more than trivial tests that were probably not worth having in the
Documentum arena. I've looked in passing at the various mocking libraries
and they looked interesting but again required too many "moving parts" to be
useful for more than trivial tests.

Documentum itself doesn't provide a testing library so I started looking at
building a kind of test library to mock Documentum itself but bogged down in
how do you test the test code.

Type Based Objects bring their own hell as they extend and overide the
existing Documentum object features in complex ways.

The only technique I've used successfully, and only to a limited extent, is
to endevour to encapsulate the non-Documentum specific logic in seperately
testable classes as Strategies etc. In some cases I was able to isolate
methods and test just those specific methods.

Michael Rutherfurd


-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
David Saff
Sent: Tuesday, 20 June 2006 10:14 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] unit test case for login()



Tejal,

One possibility is to think about things that could go wrong. For
example, I assume that docbaseSession is a field of your class. If the
last line didn't execute, and docbaseSession ended up not being
assigned, how could you detect that from outside the object?

David Saff

Tejal Khatri, Gurgaon wrote:
> Hi,
>
> I am new to junit and I have to unit test a few methods of
> a class. Out of those one of the methods is login method.
> I have undergone many examples in tutorials, but still have no
> idea about how to unit test following login method of my application.
>
> public void login(String username, String password, String docbase) throws
> Exception{
>
> try{
>
> moClientX = new DfClientX();
> IDfClient moClient = moClientX.getLocalClient();
>
>
> DfLoginInfo loLoginInfo = new DfLoginInfo();
> loLoginInfo.setUser(username);
> loLoginInfo.setPassword(password);
>
> /*create a Session Manager object*/
> sessionManager = moClient.newSessionManager();
> sessionManager.setIdentity(docbase, loLoginInfo);
> sessionManager.authenticate(docbase);
>
>
> docbaseSession = sessionManager.getSession(docbase);
>
> }catch(Exception e)
> {
> e.printStackTrace();
> throw new Exception(e.toString());
> }
> }
>
> Does anybody have any idea?
> Thanks in advance.
> Best Regards,
> Tejal
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>
